timeline.summary: On June 13, 2008, at 10:00 AM - 10:30 AM (GMT-05:00), a call was scheduled between individuals associated with USAFLS, ODAG, and SMO to discuss an “Epstein” matter. The call was to take place at an unspecified office location and could be conducted by phone. Participants included [REDACTED] and [REDACTED]. Correspondence leading up to the call occurred on June 11, 2008, with discussions regarding availability and a phone number (305) 961-9299.  Multiple individuals expressed availability for the call, with conflicting times noted.

On June 20, 2008, Kenneth W. Starr and Jay P. Lefkowitz of Kirkland & Ellis LLP sent an email to John Roth (ODAG) and others, attaching documents related to a “misconduct” and “principal submission” matter. The email requested a meeting to discuss the documents. John Roth responded, suggesting a delay in contacting Jay Lefkowitz until Monday. The email chain involved redactions and attachments including PDFs related to the subject matter.

A June 23, 2008 email was sent from the ODAG to Ken Starr, Jay Lefkowitz, and Kenneth Starr, along with Alex Acosta (USAFLS), containing a letter regarding the Jeffrey Epstein matter. The email included an attachment named scan0001.pclf.

Emails dated June 30, 2008, and July 26, 2008, detail updates regarding the legal proceedings against Jeffrey Epstein. Discussions involve legal counsel from the ODAG and USAFLS teams. Epstein’s plea occurred on June 30, 2008. Correspondence includes updates on the expected timeline for sentencing and surrender, concerns about potential delays, and a lack of communication from defense counsel. Roy Black, an attorney, communicated updates regarding the case’s conclusion. The AG’s office was informed of the defense’s silence and advised not to engage.

On December 10, 2018, individuals communicated regarding a “brief write up” related to Jeffrey Epstein that someone had sent to an unknown recipient. One person reported that the sender hadn’t yet received a response, and another inquired whether the sender had contacted ODAG.

An email was sent from the Deputy Chief, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to [REDACTED] and [REDACTED], with CC to [REDACTED], regarding a contact with the National Coordinator for Child Exploitation and Interdiction, in ODAG. The email refers to EFTA00009883.

An email chain discusses a draft status memo (2019-03-06 JE status memo to ODAG.docx). One sender ([REDACTED]) sent the memo to another ([REDACTED]), requesting feedback on its length (specifically noting a three-page limit requested by “chiefs”). The sender also included a redline version for discussion.

The FBI Florida requests consent from SDLF to transfer all grand jury materials from the original Epstein case to the USANYS. This request is based on Rule 6(e) approval for sharing grand jury materials between federal grand juries. The email discusses whether to involve the crim chief or ODAG in coordinating this transfer.

An email chain discusses a memo update regarding the Epstein case. One individual is unavailable due to travel and requested an update memo from another party. The update memo was to cover progress since the last memo and outline next steps, intended for internal use and not for distribution to DC. Attachments included two memos: an ODAG memo and a memo for Audrey.

On May 10, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein sent a revised and shortened memo for ODAG (U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, Public Corruption Unit) to Audrey Strauss, Co-Chief, Public Corruption Unit. The memo was attached to an email sent from his iPhone.

An email was sent from the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) to an unknown recipient regarding an “Epstein memo.” The email, dated May 13, 2019, included a document (“JE_status_memo_for ODAG.finaldocx.docx” and “JE_status_memo_for_ODAG.finaldocx.pdf”) and indicated revisions had been made. The sender identified themselves as being from USANYS.

A memo, dated May 15, 2019, regarding an update on the Epstein investigation was sent from EFTA00009936. The memo emphasized the need to maintain close hold and covert operations due to the sensitivity of the investigation, and invited questions. An attached document, “JE_status_memo_for ODAG.finaldocx.pdf,” provided further details.

An email exchange occurred between individuals associated with USANYS and ODAG regarding two memos related to recusal matters. One memo was from Geoff and one from the sender, concerning Ed of the DAG. Following a conversation, Epstein was added to the briefing materials. The memos themselves (SDNY Memo to DAG.GSB.cases.5.23.19.final.pdf and SDNY Memo to DAG - GSB Recused.5.23.19.Finaldocx.pdf) were shared.

An automatic reply email was sent from “[REDACTED]” (USANYS) to ODAG regarding matters requiring immediate attention, directing inquiries to EFTA00030611. The email was sent on June 11, 2019, and indicated the sender was out of the office.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York drafted and circulated an ODAG (Operational Data Analysis Group) update memo on June 19, 2019, following two previous memos. The memo, attached as a document, reflects input from the chiefs and included a request for any questions or additional information.

An email was sent from a U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York Co-Chief, Public Corruption Unit, to an unknown recipient regarding ODAG update memos. The sender notes a historical trend of these memos being related to “MC” matters, but the current memo concerns Jeffrey Epstein and requests the recipient’s preference for review before it is sent to Audrey.

An email exchange occurred between [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and [REDACTED] regarding ODAG update memos. One party requested to review the memos, particularly due to their connection to Epstein, while the other party initially intended to send them directly to Audrey. The subject of the memos was related to the Public Corruption Unit within the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York.

The Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) at the U.S. Department of Justice is assisting with a request for a non-public appendix related to the Epstein NPA. The Chief Public Corruption Unit is seeking this appendix, which contains a list of victims entitled to compensation, and inquired if ODAG had a copy or could retrieve it. The email thread indicates OPR will provide a copy separately.

On August 12, 2019, the Principal Associate Deputy Attorney General (ODAG) sent a draft letter to Congress regarding the Jeffrey Epstein matter to E.(OIG). The draft included specific statements for review and requested feedback within the hour, incorporating prior comments.

An email exchange occurred between J. (Regional Director, Northeast Region) and [REDACTED] regarding contact information for ODAG. J. forwarded information about the Warden’s private line and work cell, indicating ODAG may or may not contact the recipient or other staff. The email was sent on August 14, 2019.

On August 14, 2019, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested a memo regarding the Epstein prosecution. Attachments included memos from June 17, June 19, and June 24, 2019, related to the case, along with a report from USANYS. The sender, [REDACTED], provided the requested memo and additional related documents.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the ODAG and potential contact with other office staff. The sender requested notification if anyone reached out through the Acting Warden's Private Line or Warden's Work Cell. The email includes attachments named TEXT.htm and cf, with a file identifier of 7cbdeee3-299d-45b9-94b4-847fde1969e9.

On August 14, 2019, communications occurred regarding a memo titled “Epstein Pros.”  Multiple individuals, including Assistant United States Attorneys from the Southern District of New York, requested and provided documents related to the case, including court dates, docket information, ODAG memos, and UMRs from charging.  The correspondence involved exchanging attachments and clarifying the specific information being sought.

Emails between August 14, 2019, and the date of redaction (December 25, 2025) involve discussions regarding the Epstein case ( docket 19-490 ). The emails pertain to court dates, presentments, arraignments, bail hearings, and scheduling conferences. Attachments included court transcripts, initial conference documents, presentments, bail hearing documents, bail decisions, and a scheduling conference document. Additional documents, such as ODAG memos and UMR charging documents, were offered for review. The primary request was for information regarding the court dates and outcomes of the proceedings.

*   The meeting agenda has been revised to include a briefing with a new ODAG Liaison. *   Attendees are instructed to review their areas of responsibility and provide concise (5-minute or less) presentations. *   The Philadelphia hotel room block has been canceled, and attendees are responsible for canceling their travel arrangements. *   Meeting logistics are detailed, including the Hyatt Regency Washington location, room assignments (A-C training rooms), required identification (PIV card), and business casual attire. *   Weather forecasts and temperature ranges are provided. *   A fee of $25 will be collected for food expenses for the November 2019 meeting. *   PRD support staff will be available for assistance during the meeting.

An email was sent revising the agenda for an Executive Staff meeting scheduled for August 20, 2019, in Washington, DC. The meeting will include “Executive Staff Briefings to ODAG.” The Philadelphia hotel room block has been canceled, and attendees are responsible for canceling their own airfare/train arrangements. The meeting will be held in training rooms A-C on the first floor of the Hyatt Regency Washington on Capital Hill. Attendees are required to bring their government ID and PIV card. The dress attire is business casual, and the weather forecast is for warm, partly cloudy days. $25 will be collected from each attendee for food for the November 2019 meeting. PRD support staff will be available for assistance during the meeting.

Emails discuss assigning case WF 4319870 to the SDNY for handling. One email requests assignment to ODAG, while another directs assignment to ODAG for guidance. Attachments related to the case EFTA00021159 and EFTA00021160 are referenced.

The Department of Justice is requesting guidance on the disposition of the property belonging to the late Jeffrey Epstein. Guernsey’s Auction House has been identified as a suitable partner to maximize the property’s financial value and promote messages of support for young women. The request is directed to EOUSA and includes an attachment of a letter from Judge Burton regarding the Estate and Trust of Mrs. Rosa L. Parks. Previous attempts by CRM, BOP, and EOUSA to handle the workflow were unsuccessful, leading to assignment to ODAG and ultimately EOUSA-SDNY.

On October 9, 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), via the Executive Office for U.S. Attorneys, received a forwarded email from an unidentified sender regarding an offer from Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers to handle the disposition of Jeffrey Epstein’s property. The DOJ was assigned to respond to this matter, as advised by Nathaniel Gamble II from ODAG, and the correspondence included attachments from Arlan Ettinger, President of Guernsey’s, and a control sheet.

On October 9, 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice (USAO-SDNY) received a correspondence from Arlan Ettinger, President of Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers, regarding an offer to handle the auction of Jeffrey Epstein’s property. The initial email chain discusses a potential involvement with the auction, with the DOJ responding with a standard acknowledgement and forwarding the correspondence to Nathaniel Gamble II for further handling. The DOJ indicates that this matter has been assigned to them for review.

On October 9, 2019, correspondence regarding the disposition of Jeffrey Epstein’s property was circulated within the U.S. Department of Justice, USAO-SDNY. Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers, through Arlan Ettinger, offered to handle the sale of the property. The initial email chain sought guidance on how to respond to the offer, with a subsequent email forwarding the correspondence to the DOJ for handling, as assigned by Nathaniel Gamble II from ODAG. The DOJ responded with a standard acknowledgment of receipt and forwarding to their office for review.

On October 15, 2019, an email was sent forwarding correspondence regarding Jeffrey Epstein’s property to [REDACTED]. This correspondence included a letter from Arlan Ettinger, President of Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers, offering to handle the disposition of Epstein’s property, and an email assigning the matter to the USAO-SDNY. Another email, dated October 9, 2019, inquired about the appropriate handling of this offer. Nathaniel Gamble II from ODAG had previously assigned the matter to the USAO-SDNY.

On October 15, 2019, the U.S. Department of Justice, via the Executive Office for U.S. Attorneys, received correspondence regarding Jeffrey Epstein’s property. This included an email from Arlan Ettinger of Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers offering to handle the disposition of the property, and a forwarded email from Nathaniel Gamble II assigning the matter to the USAO-SDNY. The correspondence was requested to be filed appropriately.

A series of emails discuss questions related to victim impact statements in the Epstein case. Seventeen victims attended a hearing and spoke or had statements read for them, with an additional seven participating remotely. One victim group raised concerns regarding insufficient notice and travel limitations preventing some victims from speaking at the hearing. An appeal was filed alleging insufficient opportunity for victims to participate due to lack of notice and travel restrictions. The request seeks information on the number of victims contacted, those who attended in person, and those unable to attend due to notice/timing.

Emails dated January 15, 2020, October 9, 2019, and January 17, 2020, detail the handling of correspondence from Arlan Ettinger, President of Guernsey’s Auctioneers & Brokers, regarding the property of Jeffrey Epstein. The USAO-SDNY was assigned to handle the matter, following advice from Nathaniel Gamble II from ODAG.  A request for a district response was initiated as part of a close-out process.

The document is a series of email exchanges regarding a request for assistance with locating documents related to the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. Key points include: *   Multiple individuals (USANYS, ODAG, USANYS, OPR, SDFL, NDGA) are involved in coordinating document retrieval efforts. *   A dial-in meeting was proposed for Thursday at noon. *   Discussion centered on identifying appropriate document custodians within various organizations (ODAG, SDFL, NDGA, OPR). *   OPR was suggested as a potential resource due to a previous document collection effort. *   The US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) is seeking assistance from other agencies regarding discovery requests related to the SDFL investigation and NPA. *   There’s a focus on recusal issues and potential consequences related to the litigation.

The document consists of email exchanges regarding a request for documents related to the Epstein/Maxwell investigations. Discussions involve multiple parties including USANYS, ODAG, SDFL, NDGA, and OPR.  A central concern is identifying document custodians and coordinating a discussion about potential document collection, particularly regarding the SDFL and NPA investigations.  A key point is the recusal of one individual (Associate Deputy Attorney General) due to the CVRA litigation and a lack of SDFL documents. The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York is actively pursuing Ghislaine Maxwell's case and revisiting prior conversations about document requests.

This document is a series of email exchanges regarding the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, specifically concerning the location of relevant documents. Key points include: *   Multiple parties (USANYS, USANYS, ODAG, MAO, SDFL, NDGA, OPR) are involved in coordinating efforts to locate documents. *   Requests are made to contact individuals within the Southern District of New York’s (SDFL) Criminal Division, specifically a US Attorney and a Criminal Chief, to obtain copies of criminal files. *   There’s an inquiry about the best point of contact within the SDFL for document retrieval, given prior conversations with OPR and the CVRA litigation. *   Discussions involve identifying document custodians (OPR, M.) and exploring potential contacts within SDFL and NDGA related to document collection. *   A U.S. Attorney’s Office representative offers to discuss recusal issues and directs contact to the SDFL. *   Scheduling of a call for July 22, 2020, to discuss document requests is repeatedly proposed.

A call occurred on July 23, 2020, from 16:00:00 to 16:30:00 GMT, regarding Epstein/Maxwell documents. The organizer was (USANYS) [REDACTED], and (ODAG) attended. The event was classified as X-PERSONAL and had a priority of 5. A reminder was set to display a message 15 minutes before the start. The document identifier is EFTA00015837.

On August 18, 2020, a call occurred between USANYS and MMIMME> regarding the SDNY-ODAG call involving Epstein and Maxwell. The call was titled “SDNY-ODAG Call (Epstein/Maxwell)” and attached to email EFTA00020339.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding the acceptance of the SDNY-ODAG Call (Epstein/Maxwell). The email is dated August 18, 2020, and includes attachments named “unnamed.” The email subject line is "Accepted: SDNY-ODAG Call (Epstein/Maxwell)."
An email was accepted titled “Accepted: SDNY-ODAG Call (Epstein/Maxwell)” from [REDACTED] on August 18, 2020, with the file name EFTA00017839.

On August 19, 2020, at 2:00 PM +0000, a meeting (Conf. Id 758788) took place with the designation "X-PERSONAL" under the SDNY-ODAG Call (Epstein/Maxwell). The meeting was created on August 18, 2020, and assigned priority 5 to EFTA00017840.

An FBI briefing call, designated EFTA00038046, took place on October 16, 2020, from 16:00:00 to 17:00:00 GMT. The organizer was the FBI, and attendees included representatives from ODAG, JMD, and NY (FBI). The call was marked as X-PERSONAL and had a priority of 5. A reminder message was to be displayed 15 minutes before the start, and the dial-in numbers were 303-586-4335 and 1-877-446-3914 with a guest passcode. The call was related to a conversation with SA.

This email provides dial-in information for a call regarding the Epstein Briefing. The call is between the FBI (DO and NY) and ODAG (JMD) and CRT. The email was sent on October 20, 2020, with the subject "Epstein Briefing Check-In."

An email chain discusses an ODAG/FBI briefing conference call scheduled for November 2, 2020, at 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM UTC-05:00 Eastern Time. The call details include the conference line number EFTA00038161 and a guest passcode EFTA00038162. Attachments include a master list of attendees and an RSVP tracking spreadsheet. The email originates from multiple FBI and ODAG entities.

An email chain discusses an ODAG/FBI briefing conference call scheduled for November 2, 2020, at 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time. Attachments include a Survivor Master list with highlighted victim contact information and an RSVP tracking spreadsheet. The FBI is following up on Sigrid’s victim list and a Dubai request.  The call involves participants from ODAG, FBI, CRT, and NY (FBI).

An email chain discusses draft talking points for a victim briefing regarding child exploitation and human trafficking. The Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG), specifically the Acting Chief Privacy and Civil Liberties Officer (OPCL), requests input and comments on the talking points, including topics to avoid or expand upon, with a deadline of November 10, 2020. The email involves multiple recipients within the U.S. Department of Justice including OPR, OPR, OPCL, OLA, USAGAN, and USANYS.

A debriefing titled “ODAG Epstein Debrief” was canceled on November 16, 2020, from 20:30:00 to 21:30:00 GMT. The event was organized under the classification “X-PERSONAL” and created on November 16, 2020, at 18:22:01 GMT.  It was assigned a priority of 1 and attendee invitations were sent.

A debriefing titled “ODAG Epstein Debrief” was scheduled for November 16, 2020, from 20:30 to 21:30. The event was canceled and was designated as X-PERSONAL. The meeting was created on November 16, 2020, and last modified on November 17, 2020. It had a priority of 1.
An email was sent canceling a debrief titled “ODAG Epstein” from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] on November 16, 2020. An invitation had already been sent. The document is identified as EFTA00038144.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding an “ODAG Epstein Debrief.” The email, dated November 16, 2020, included a call and a guest passcode (EFTA00038149). Two redactions are present on page 1.

An ODAG Epstein debriefing event took place on November 16, 2020, from 20:30:00 to 21:30:00 GMT. The event was organized, attended, and created by individuals identified as EFTA00038150. It had a priority of 5 and included a reminder with the message "CALL" and a guest passcode of EFTA00038150. A display alarm was scheduled to activate 5 minutes before the start.

An email exchange occurred between two individuals regarding updates to ODAG and a potential announcement about non-pros. One individual mentioned discussing the matter with another person named Epstein, but noted no current discussion about Epstein’s involvement in the case. The email concluded with a statement of “done; no comment yet.”
